awd_titl_txt: The Fate of Subducted Carbon Dioxide During Metamorphism, Syros and Tinos Islands, Greece
awd_abstract_narration:
Earth's subduction zones are marked by the deep ocean trenches where one tectonic plate sinks (subducts) beneath another into Earth's mantle, commonly at speeds of inches per year. Subduction zones are of critical societal importance because they host the world's largest earthquakes - including those that produce deadly tsunamis - and the most destructive volcanoes. Moreover, subduction is a driver of the geological carbon cycle, a prerequisite for Earth's temperate climate and life. Roughly a hundred million tons of carbon stored in rocks are subducted each year across the globe. Yet major disagreements surround how much of this carbon, mostly in the form of carbon dioxide, is actually released from subduction zones to make the journey back to the surface. Is this carbon dioxide largely taken deep into Earth's mantle, or does the bulk of it ascend to ultimately interact with the atmosphere and hydrosphere? The proposed work will shed light on these questions by determining the nature, processes, and amounts of carbon transport recorded by the spectacularly-exposed fossil subduction complexes of Syros and Tinos islands, Greece. This is a necessary step for quantifying natural and anthropogenic (human) contributions to the long-term evolution of climate and climate change. 

The proposed work is a field-based petrological study of metamorphic decarbonation processes involving serpentinite-chlorite mélange (Syros, Tinos) and metasedimentary mélange (Tinos) intercalated or tectonically juxtaposed with metavolcanic, metaclastic, and metacarbonate rocks. The closed- and open-system behavior of carbonate-bearing lithologies will be quantified to determine the degree of external fluid infiltration and make maps of fluid composition and time-integrated devolatilization fluxes. This has not been done before at a regional scale in subduction complexes. The proposal goals will be achieved via thermodynamic modeling of fluid chemistry based on measured rock and mineral compositions; Raman spectroscopy of fluid inclusions to identify simple (e.g. water-carbon dioxide) or more complex fluids containing dissolved solutes; oxygen and carbon stable isotope work to assess fluid sources and flow pathways; and mineral and bulk-rock chemical analyses to determine metasomatic reactions. Quantitative estimates of carbon dioxide transport will provide important new inputs to models of the geologic carbon cycle. The work will support a Ph.D. student from an under-represented group in science as well as several undergraduates, and produce educational modules about the carbon cycle for both the Yale Peabody Museum of Natural History and the Natural History Museum of Crete, Greece.

por.por_cntn:
Earth's subduction zones are marked by deep ocean trenches. Here, tectonic plates sink (or "subduct") into Earth's mantle at rates of centimeters per year. The subduction zones comprising the "Ring of Fire" encircling the Pacific Ocean are a classic example. The subducted plates, or "slabs", undergo conditions of increasing pressure and temperature as they descend and become metamorphosed. This metamorphism, in turn, promotes chemical reactions in slabs that release water, carbon dioxide (CO2), and other fluid components ("volatiles") to the mantle. The fluids then drive melting reactions in the mantle, producing magmas that ascend and ultimately give rise to explosive "arc magma" volcanism on plate margins as well as the associated volcanic hazards (e.g., Mount St. Helens, Washington Cascades). The magmatic activity is also critical for producing valuable metal deposits, including many important deposits of copper and gold worldwide.

Subduction zones are thus critically important for returning volatiles to Earth's interior, and for releasing them back to the surface via volcanic eruptions. In this way, subduction zones place fundamental controls on volatile cycling for our planet. A major unresolved problem, however, is determinng how much of the CO2 that enters subduction zones is released during subduction, and how much is retained and subducted deep into Earth's mantle. Our project addressed this problem using an integrative field-based study of metamorphic rocks in the subduction complexes exposed on the Greek islands of Syros and Tinos.

The CO2 is carried by slabs into subduction zones by carbonate minerals such as calcite and aragonite (CaCO3). When pressure and temperature increase during subduction, these minerals participate in metamorphic devolatilization reactions that liberate varying amounts of the mineral-bound CO2. We developed methods to quantify this CO2 loss and thereby place constraints on the amount of CO2 that is released to the mantle by such reactions.

We find that these metamorphic volatile contributions to the global carbon cycle are an underappreciated flux that can release ~65% of the rock-hosted CO2 to the overlying mantle, with a large pulse around 60 km depth below the surface (see accompanying figure). This release, coupled with additional release processes that operate over the 60 to 150 km depth range (e.g., dissolution, melting), puts considerable limits on the amount of subducted CO2 that can be returned to Earth's deep mantle at depths greater than about 150 km.

As a consequence, our results preclude large-scale deep subduction of most CO2. A major implication, therefore, is that the mantle has become increasingly depleted in carbon over geologic time. Furthermore, the deep mantle may continue to be depleted in carbon well into the future. Far into the future (million-to-billion-year timescales) the reduction in the amount of deep mantle CO2 returned to the surface environment by intraplate and mid-ocean ridge volcanism could lead to atmospheric cooling. We emphasize, however, that while the deep-Earth CO2 fluxes we calculate could influence the global carbon cycle on million-to-billion-year timescales, they are miniscule compared to today's anthropogenic CO2 emissions.

The award supported the scientific training of seven undergraduate and graduate students at Yale, five of whom are from traditionally underrepresented groups in STEM. Results were disseminated widely at international conferences, in international peer-reviewed journals, in a Ph.D. thesis, and in a textbook. Furthermore, instructional materials on the deep carbon cycle were prepared for public outreach and educational programs at the Natural History Museum of Crete and the Yale Peabody Museum of Natural History.
